column_a:
commodity /ˈkɒm.əd.ɪt/,
Examples:
The market's commodity prices were highly volatile this month.
Fresh fruit and vegetables are often sold as individual items, rather than commodities in the global markets.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun, adjective
Definition: 	1. {'primary': 'A basic good used in commerce that is interchangeable with other goods of its type.', 'secondary': ['Anything produced or distributed for commercial trade.']}
Synonyms: good, product, asset
Antonyms: service

column_a:
snub /ˈsnʌb/
Examples:
He was quick to snub her at the party.
They felt hurt after being publicly snubbed during a meeting.
column_b:
Part of Speech: verb
Definition: 	1. {'definition': "to rudely ignore or dismiss by refusing to acknowledge someone'senvironment."}
Synonyms: ignore, disregard, overlook, reject
Antonyms: acknowledge, accept, recognize, admire

column_a:
impetuous /ˌɪmpɛtʃuˈəs/
Examples:
In an impetuous rage, he knocked over the entire vase collection

succumbed /ˌsukjʊˈmɛdb/
Examples:
After weeks of denial, he finally succumbed to the evidence.
The soldiers could not hold back and slowly began to succumb under enemy fire.
column_b:
Part of Speech: verb
Definition: 	1. to yield to a superior force or influence; give in.
Synonyms: give up, yield, surrender
Antonyms: resist, withstand, endure

column_a:
secularized /ˌsɛkjʊˈlæɪ.zeɪ.ʃeɪt/
Examples:
The process of **secularizing** the education system was controversial
Many modern countries have a very **secularized** culture
column_b:
Part of Speech: verb and adjective
Definition: 	1. as a verb
	2. as an adjective
Synonyms: rationalize, naturalize
Antonyms: religionize, sanctify

column_a:
emanates /ˌiːmeɪˈneɪtiz/
Examples:
The roses emanate a sweet fragrance.
Her voice seemed to emanate from her very soul.

flounder /ˈflʌndər/
Examples:
He floundered through his presentation because he was not prepared
The codfish tends to roll and look confused when caught, as if it were trying to 'flounder'
column_b:
Part of Speech: verb and noun
Definition: 	1. noun
	2. verb
Synonyms: noun, verb
Antonyms: noun, verb

column_a:
eminently /iˈmɪnəntli/
Examples:
She was eminently qualified for the job.
He moved with ease, in an eminently graceful manner.

embroiled /ɪˈmroʊbl/
Examples:
The two neighbors became embroiled in a bitter feud over property lines.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. involved in an argument or disagreement; heatedly debating.
	2. embroiled (noun) - a person who is embroiled.
Synonyms: entangled, mired
Antonyms: uninvolved, clear-headed

column_a:
transfixed /ˌtransˈfɪsl/
Examples:
The magician made us all transfixed as he pulled a rabbit out of his hat.
She was completely transfixed by the beauty of the garden.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective or verb
Definition: 	1. verb
	2. adjective
Synonyms: fascinated, mesmerized
Antonyms: bored, uninterested

column_a:
anthropologist /ˌænθrəˈpɒlɪstr/,
Examples:
The anthropologist spent years researching tribal customs.
She hopes to become a renowned cultural anthropologist.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. A person who studies human societies and cultures (especially in the past).
	2. An academic professional specializing in anthropology.
Synonyms: ethnographer, cultural scientist
Antonyms: misanthrope, xenophobe

column_a:
niche /ˈniːʃ/
Examples:
She found her niche in eco-tourism.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. A specialized section of the market for a particular kind of product.
	2. The position, role, or activity suited to someone's abilities.
Synonyms: specialty, field of expertise
Antonyms: general marketplace, misfit role or activity

column_a:
culminating /ˌkʌl.mɪnˈeɪ.tʃɪŋ/
Examples:
The most successful businesses are often those that have been building their foundation over many years, rather than trying for quick gains—culminating in steady growth is typically more sustainable. - Michael Lewis
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective and gerund (as a verb)
Definition: 	1. adjective
	2. gerund
Synonyms: ultimate, pinnacle, apex
Antonyms: beginning, trough

column_a:
stifled /ˈstɪftəld/
Examples:
The toddler felt stifled by all of her little sister’s antics.
His speech was drowned out, feeling utterly stifled amidst the noise of protesters chanting outside his window.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. lacking fresh air or space for free movement; cramped: 'a stifled crowd in the tiny room'.
Synonyms: constricted, suppressed
Antonyms: spacious, unhampered

column_a:
chastened /ˈtæstɪnd/
Examples:
The teacher chastened the disruptive student with a stern look
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective and verb
Definition: 	1. as_verb
	2. as_adjective
Synonyms: rebuked, scolded
Antonyms: encouraged

column_a:
provincials /prɪvənsiɛlz/
Examples:
The provincials were not accustomed to the sophistication of urban life.
Some felt that their small town upbringing made them less competitive in an international marketplace.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective and noun
Definition: 	1. as an adjective
	2. as a noun
Synonyms: rural folks, country bumpkins
Antonyms: city dwellers, urbanites

column_a:
rigorous /ˈrɪɡ.jʊ.ə.sə(ɹ)/
Examples:
The professor expects rigorous academic standards from his students.
She followed a very rigorous exercise routine to maintain her health.

rekindled /rekˈild/
Examples:
Their friendship, once thought lost forever among the ashes of war and time itself, had been rekindled.
column_b:
Part of Speech: verb
Definition: 	1. To ignite again; to revive (as a feeling); typically followed by 'to'
Synonyms: revived, renewed
Antonyms: extinguished, diminished

column_a:
maneuvers /ˈmɛnjərˌvɜrs/
Examples:
The general ordered some clever maneuvers on the battlefield.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: 	1. noun
	2. verb
Synonyms: tactics, strategies
Antonyms: stagnation

column_a:
complacency /ˌkɒm.plæˈsiː.ʃn̩/
Examples:
The team was not content to win a league title; they showed complacency after the victory.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. uncritical self-satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements
	2. a complacent person
Synonyms: self-contentment, smugness, laziness
Antonyms: awareness, humility, conscientiousness

column_a:
tactile /ˈtæktɪl/
Examples:
The tactile sensation reminded her of silk against her skin.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. {'standard': 'of or relating to the sense of touch'}
Synonyms: touchable, palpable, perceptible
Antonyms: invisible

column_a:
oar /ˈɔr/
Examples:
He paddled the boat by oaring furiously
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. A long pole with a flat blade at one end used for rowing watercraft.
	2. To propel or steer in this way.
Synonyms: paddle, rowboat handle
Antonyms: footrest

column_a:
propel /prəˈpel/
Examples:
The engine propelled the car down the highway.
Rockets are designed to be easily propelled into space.

bleaker /ˈbleɪkər/
Examples:
With every passing day in quarantine, the situation seemed bleaker.
As the rumors spread of layoffs at work, morale plummeted to a truly dismal state - it was all so terribly bleak. (source: The New York Times)
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. {'definition': 'having or showing no hope, encouragement; gloomy.'}
Synonyms: gloomy, dismal, desolate
Antonyms: hopeful, bright

column_a:
attestation /əˈtɛstɪʃn/
Examples:
He had no other proof than the witness's deathbed attestation.
The court required clear and convincing evidence, but he submitted only his personal testimony which lacked proper attestation from a credible source.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. {'sentence1': 'The notarized document served as attestation of his identity.', 'sentence2': 'She provided a sworn statement that acted as an official testament to her claims.'}
Synonyms: testimony, verification, confirmation
Antonyms: denial, refutation

column_a:
obscure /ɒbˈskjuər/
Examples:
The ancient manuscript contained some of the most obscure writings known to exist.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. not clear or plain; not easily seen or understood: 'an obscure passage in the text'
	2. unknown, uncertain
Synonyms: unclear, confusing, incomprehensible, vague, mysterious
Antonyms: clear, crystal clear, obvious, evident, plain

column_a:
assailed /əˈseɪld/
Examples:
The protesters were assailed with tear gas
column_b:
Part of Speech: verb
Definition: 	1. To attack someone or something violently.
	2. To assault mentally, such as by criticizing harshly.
Synonyms: attacked, harassed
Antonyms: protected, sheltered

column_a:
diversions /dɪˈvɜr.ʒən.ʃəz/
Examples:
The movie included several diversions for the younger audience.
She enjoyed a variety of music and art exhibits, which were great cultural diversions from her daily routine.
column_b:
Part of Speech: Noun
Definition: 	1. Such things as are intended to divert attention or interest: amusements.
Synonyms: entertainments, amusements
Antonyms: concentrations

column_a:
menial /ˈmɛn.ɪ.əl/
Examples:
The maid performed her menial duties with diligence and precision.
He had spent his life doing nothing more than menial tasks without recognition or advancement.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective and noun
Definition: 	1. adjective
	2. noun
Synonyms: servile, submissive, inferior
Antonyms: proud, autonomous

column_a:
menial /ˈmɛn.ɪ.əl/
Examples:

Examples:

Part of Speech: verb and adjective
Definition: 	1. as a verb
	2. as an adjective
Synonyms: rationalize, naturalize
Antonyms: religionize, sanctify

snub /ˈsnʌb/
Examples:
He was quick to snub her at the party.
They felt hurt after being publicly snubbed during a meeting.
column_b:
Part of Speech: verb
Definition: 	1. {'definition': "to rudely ignore or dismiss by refusing to acknowledge someone'senvironment."}
Synonyms: ignore, disregard, overlook, reject
Antonyms: acknowledge, accept, recognize, admire

column_a:
daemon /ˈdiːmən/
Examples:
The old house was haunted by ghosts, but some believed it had friendly daemons as well.
column_b:
Part of Speech: Noun, Verb (archaic)
Definition: 	1. primary
	2. secondary
Synonyms: spirit, ghost
Antonyms: deity

column_a:
wedlock /ˈweð.lɔk/
Examples:
They celebrated their wedlock with a trip to Europe.
Getting into wedlock was the couple's dream since they were young.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. The state of being legally married.
	2. A marriage between two people.
Synonyms: matrimony, nuptiality
Antonyms: divorce

column_a:
bourgeoisie /boʊrˈʒuːz/
Examples:
The bourgeie turned on their newfound wealth with extravagance.
Cultural tastes often reflect those of the urban bourgeieu, especially after World War II.

elitist /ɪˈlaɪ.tɪst/,
Examples:
The political candidate's opponents accused him of being elitist.
She felt unwelcome at the exclusive event, which seemed to cater only to elitists.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. {'definition': 'having or showing a snobbish air of superiority.'}
Synonyms: snobbish, arrogant
Antonyms: populist, accessible, egalitarian

column_a:
contemporary /ˌkɒn.tɪˈmɜː.pər.tli/
Examples:
Her work is considered very contemporary.
Modern art often features prominent contemporary artists.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective, noun, verb
Definition: 	1. as_an_adjective
	2. as_a_noun
Synonyms: current, modern, present-day
Antonyms: ancient, obsolete

column_a:
institutions /ˌɪnstɪˈtjuːʃəntz/
Examples:
Educational institutions are vital to society's progress.
Many people find solace in the supportive environment provided by spiritual institutions.
column_b:
Part of Speech: Noun plural
Definition: 	1. Organizations established for a particular purpose.
	2. Foundations, especially of learning or of religious belief.
Synonyms: organizations, establishments, foundations
Antonyms: individualists

column_a:
lucrative /ˈlʊk.rə.tɪv/
Examples:
She found the job very lucrative, with benefits and good pay.
Investing in real estate can be quite lucrative if done wisely.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. yielding a great deal of money; profitable
Synonyms: profitable, remunerative
Antonyms: non-lucrative, ineffective

column_a:
patriarchal /ˌpæt.raɪˈkɑː.rɪ.kl̩/
Examples:
The patriarchal society was resistant to change
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. Relating to the social system where males dominate, especially in a family or religious organization.
	2. Characterized by the rule of men; having male authority.
Synonyms: androcentric, male-dominated
Antonyms: egalitarian

column_a:
fostering /ˈfɒstə(r)/
Examples:
The couple decided to **foster** three siblings.
She has been working hard at **fostering** a positive learning environment for her students.

eroded /ˈɪərˌeɪ d/
Examples:
The riverbanks had become heavily eroded after years of flooding.
His words were so persuasive, they seemed almost like an erosion of my own beliefs.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. {'definition': 'Worn away by long exposure to the elements; declined in integrity or value over time.'}
Synonyms: worn down, decayed
Antonyms: rebuilt, fortified

column_a:
palatable /ˌpæləˈteɪtəl/
Examples:
The soup is not only nutritious but also quite palatable.
After trying various diets, she found that a balanced meal was the most palatable option for her health and pleasure.

apparent /ˌæpəˈrɛnt/
Examples:
The apparent winner of the race was disqualified later.
Her smile, although she seemed unconcerned, appeared genuine and sincere.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. clearly visible or obvious; easily perceived.
Synonyms: obvious, evident
Antonyms: hidden, undetectable

column_a:
innate /ˌɪnəˈteit/
Examples:
His warmth is innate.
The strength of the eagles was evident from their size and powerful wings – an example that they simply couldn’t fake. I know this because it seemed so very natural to them; instinctive as any animal might do, yet even more refined.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. Inherent; natural to a person or animal as in behavior, qualities, etc.
Synonyms: inborn, instinctual
Antonyms: acquired, manufactured

column_a:
groomed /ɡruːmd/
Examples:
The groomed gentleman left for the party at sunset
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective and past participle of verb
Definition: 	1. having one's hair cut, washed, and styled in order to look neat
Synonyms: polished, tidy, neatly dressed
Antonyms: unkempt, messy, untidy

column_a:
barnacles /ˈbɑːrnəks/
Examples:
The barnacles grew on the hull of our boat
He looked at his new coworker and thought he had a few old, nasty-looking barnacles attached to him
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. Small, hard-shelled crustaceans that attach themselves to surfaces in marine environments.
	2. Anything or anyone regarded as repulsive.
Synonyms: cirripedes
Antonyms: cleansers

column_a:
drudgery /ˈdrʌdʒəri/
Examples:
The farmer's drudgery in the fields was evident as he sank into his usual tired slump by noon.
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. Labour or work that is dull, exhausting, and unpleasant.
	2. Repeated toilsome tasks.
Synonyms: toil, gruntwork
Antonyms: pleasure, ease

column_a:
uncanny /ʌnˈkæni/,
Examples:
It's almost uncanny how these old buildings still stand after all this time.
She had an uncanny ability to remember every word he said during their conversations.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. having or seeming little of the natural quality ordinarily associated with something (an animal, person); strange in a mysterious way.
Synonyms: strange, peculiar, mysterious
Antonyms: ordinary, familiar, natural

column_a:
grain /ɡreɪn/
Examples:
She sprinkled rice grain over the dish, creating an artistic pattern.
The farmers decided to plant more grain this year due to increased demand.
column_b:
Part of Speech: Noun, Verb
Definition: 	1. as a noun
	2. as a verb
Synonyms: cereal, kernel
Antonyms: aggregate

column_a:
subtlest /ˈsʌbtlɪst/
Examples:
The effects of climate change were the subtlest things I ever witnessed.
A glance at her artwork revealed its subtlest beauty.
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. very slight; so subtle as to be difficult or impossible to observe directly.
Synonyms: subtle, slight
Antonyms: obvious, blatant

column_a:
primate /ˈpræm.tɪ.t/
Examples:
The study of primatology often involves observing how they use tools in their natural habitat
In some societies, anthropologists believe understanding our closest relatives, the non-human primates can shed light on human evolution
column_b:
Part of Speech: noun
Definition: 	1. A member of the biological order Primates, which includes humans and other mammals with a relatively large brain and complex behavior.
	2. An individual animal belonging to this category.
Synonyms: mammalian
Antonyms: invertebrate

column_a:
subtler /ˈsʌtlər/
Examples:
The subtler way of achieving this effect is through lighting rather than color alone
column_b:
Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: 	1. {'text': 'more careful or delicate in manner, taste, etc.'}
Synonyms: careful, delicate, discreet
Antonyms: blunt, rude, brash
